message_1: Suppose a set of data contains 10 observations: {4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, 32, 36, 40}. Calculate the median, the mean, and the standard deviation using the robust measures of central tendency and dispersion.
message_2:
To calculate the median, mean, and standard deviation of the given dataset, we will first find the median, then the mean, and finally the standard deviation.

1. Median:
The median is the middle value of a dataset when the data is sorted in ascending order. Since there are 10 observations in the dataset, the median will be the average of the 5th and 6th observations.

(20 + 24) / 2 = 22

The median of the dataset is 22.

2. Mean:
The mean is the sum of all the observations divided by the number of observations.

(4 + 8 + 12 + 16 + 20 + 24 + 28 + 32 + 36 + 40) / 10 = 220 / 10 = 22

The mean of the dataset is 22.

3. Standard Deviation:
The standard deviation is a measure of dispersion in the dataset. To calculate the standard deviation, we will first find the variance and then take the square root of the variance.

Step 1: Calculate the mean (already calculated above as 22)
Step 2: Subtract the mean from each observation and square the result
(4-22)^2 = 324
(8-22)^2 = 196
(12-22)^2 = 100
(16-22)^2 = 36
(20-22)^2 = 4
(24-22)^2 = 4
(28-22)^2 = 36
(32-22)^2 = 100
(36-22)^2 = 196
(40-22)^2 = 324

Step 3: Calculate the mean of the squared differences
(324 + 196 + 100 + 36 + 4 + 4 + 36 + 100 + 196 + 324) / 10 = 1320 / 10 = 132

Step 4: Take the square root of the mean of the squared differences
√132 ≈ 11.49

The standard deviation of the dataset is approximately 11.49.

In summary, the median is 22, the mean is 22, and the standard deviation is approximately 11.49.
